text.p: Following are the main stories in Slovenia's Monday morning newspapers:

- Slovenian Foreign Minister Zoran Thaler starts official visit to Poland on Monday in order to strenghten cooperation between the two states, which both hope to join Western political and military alliances.
- On Sunday a tough new anti-smoking law came into effect, whereby bar and restaurant owners will be fined by up to 250,000 tolars ($1,613) if customers smoke in a no-smoking section.
- Marjan Senjur, Minister of Economic Relations and Development opened a three-day annual bourse seminar in the coastal resort Portoroz on Sunday.
- Number of visitors to Slovenian coastal hotels this weekend rose to 6,375, a 17 percent increase compared to the same time last year.
- March trade deficit widened to $154.8 million from $95.7 million in February and from $134.4 million in March last year, the Slovenian Statistical Office said.
- Janez Podobnik, Slovenian parliamentary speaker, visited Pope John Paul II on Sunday to mark the anniversary of the Pope's visit to Slovenia last year.

- Newton Charles Subano from Kenya won the 17th international marathon in Radenci, 190 kilometers (116 miles) east from Ljubljana on Sunday. Some 3,000 runners participated in Slovenia's biggest marathon.
